title: Computer Vision in Indian Agriculture
summary: Startups and ICAR are using CNN-powered apps to diagnose crop diseases from smartphone photos, helping smallholder farmers across India.
content:
Case Study: AI-Powered Crop Disease Detection

India has over 120 million smallholder farmers, many without access to agricultural extension services. Crop disease can wipe out a season's income — and delayed diagnosis worsens outcomes.

The AI System

Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) trained on hundreds of thousands of plant leaf images can identify diseases with accuracy matching or exceeding agronomists. Apps like Plantix and ICAR-backed platforms let farmers photograph affected leaves and receive instant diagnoses with treatment recommendations.

Impact

Early pilots in Maharashtra and Punjab showed 30-40% reduction in unnecessary pesticide use when farmers received accurate AI diagnoses. NITI Aayog has highlighted AI agriculture as a priority for India's 2047 vision.

Key Learning

Transfer learning allows CNNs trained on ImageNet to be fine-tuned on agricultural datasets with limited labelled data — making this technology accessible to resource-constrained organisations.
